Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The COVID-19 Pandemic and Changes in the Stress Response: Identifying Risk and Resilience in Adults and Children

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: For families with young children, the COVID-19 pandemic constitutes a major life stressor that is accompanied by heightened daily demands, including lack of childcare, altered work expectations, job insecurity, and social distancing. All of these are compounded by pressing concerns about the direct and indirect impacts of the disease on family members’ health. An abundance of research has documented the negative effects of stress and instability within families and on child development in particular. There is relative lack of data, however, on factors that may protect children against the effects of such an unprecedented set of stressors. The current study will evaluate risk and resilience factors that influence how families respond to the stress, and identify family characteristics and parenting behaviors that promote children’s well-being, focusing on those from socioeconomically disadvantaged backgrounds who are most impacted by these unprecedented threats to health and social stability. <br/><br/>Prospective studies investigating the effects of a pandemic on psychological and physiological functioning in U.S. families have the potential to greatly contribute to our understanding of how children and adults cope with stress. The current study will capitalize on an ongoing longitudinal study of stress and adaptation in families with young children. The research will address fundamental questions about the effects of a chronic stressor on psychological adjustment, as well as the biological mechanisms by which stress affects health. Importantly, by examining patterns of socialization and variation in parenting, results of the study will highlight parental behaviors that may be protective. Utilizing a multi-method approach, the study incorporates questionnaire, and observational and physiological assessments, during the early period of the pandemic and approximately six months later. Comparing these data to those collected prior to the pandemic onset will allow modeling of trajectories, and the possibility of testing mediating and moderating mechanisms. The study will examine not only longitudinal change and individual variability in stress physiology and well-being, but also stress proliferation within families and the extent to which self-regulatory competencies and positive parenting including emotion socialization buffer against negative outcomes in children.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our NSF RAPID grant: The COVID-19 Pandemic and Changes in the Stress Response: Identifying Risk and Resilience in Adults and Children had a large impact at multiple levels ranging from its effect on individual students to the field of developmental science. In particular, NSF funding played a pivotal role in training and mentoring students and contributed significantly to our understanding of risk and resilience factors of parents and their young children during the COVID-19 pandemic. The grant fostered collaborations among two small liberal arts colleges (Claremont McKenna College and Pomona College) and a large research hospital (Brigham and Women’s Hospital).

The funding allowed the research team to collect data on over 150 mothers and their children. The data is rare as we utilized a multimethod approach to collect survey, interview, and biological data on a diverse set of families. Importantly, this dataset is also unique due to its longitudinal nature. We had data on these families from before the pandemic, and the NSF RAPID mechanism was timely, enabling us to collect data at initial stages of the pandemic and an additional time point thereafter. Our success also facilitated additional internal funding which further allowed us to assess families at an additional time point, when vaccines became widely available. These resources together ensured longitudinal assessments, and thus provided a design that we allow us to test hypotheses involving how the pandemic exerted its influence on parents and children as the course of the pandemic changed over time. 

Funding for this project allowed us to train over 40 undergraduate students, post-baccalaureate scholars, and graduate students. These students were involved in all stages of the research process from hypothesis generation to data collection and manuscript preparation. Their involvement in the grant contributed to their ability to gain positions at institutions such as Stanford University, University of California, Irvine, and the University of Washington to name a few. It supported the research of three co-principal investigators as well as multiple collaborators.

In addition, research findings from our ongoing work shed light on the extent to which the pandemic affected the mental health of mothers and their young children. Several of our research findings using the initial time points have been published. We have shown, for example, changes in maternal depressive symptoms and behavior problems from pre to post pandemic, and provided support for stress proliferation models emphasizing the impact of the pandemic on child outcomes as mediated by maternal influences. We have also contributed foundational research towards understanding how biomarkers may serve as vulnerability factors. Last, we shed light on variables that predict engagement in COVID-19 health recommended behaviors. By the end of the grant period, we had published one book and five journal articles. We also have multiple papers in preparation or under review, in addition to conference presentations.  While we have made significant progress in disseminating the research, we expect to be publishing from this dataset for several years. 

Our research in preparation will shed light on factors that promote the adjustment of families under stress. We are focusing on behaviors, individual characteristics, and systems-level variables that may serve as protective factors. In addition, we are examining the way in which parents discuss the pandemic with their children and their relations to child outcomes. Our goals are to identify best strategies and intervention practices for future stressful events. 

In addition, the grant allowed us to set up new protocols, systems, and structures for virtual data collection. We created an online website [scientistmommy.com] that was used to provide instructions and as a recruitment protocol for our research. In addition, we created videos that will help other researchers with learning the logistics of remote collection of biological data. We also hope to use the website to disseminate research findings. 

In sum, funding from NSF was integral by providing our team with an opportunity to contribute significantly to our understanding of children and families during the pandemic. In particular, NSF funding allowed us to examine psychological processes that underlie stress experiences in these populations, revealing key insights about the influence among family members within stress processes. This funding also created meaningful training opportunities and collaborations that propelled the professional development for the next generation of developmental scientists.
